bib.title: Neutron production double differential cross sections for 100 MeV neutron incidence on In

free_txt: Experiments were performed at the
Weapons Neutron Research (WNR) facility in Los Alamos
Neutron Science Center (LANSCE)
Compiled by S.H.
The energy spectra of emitted neutrons were
derived from unfolding their deposition-energy
spectra with the responses of the detectors, measured
individually for each detector.
NE213 liquid organic scintillators 12.7 cm
thick and 12.7 cm in diameter were used as neutron
detectors. In the first phase of the experiment
response function of each NE213 liquid organic
scintillator was measured by recording the charge
from the photomultiplier connected to the NE213
scintillator and the time-of-flight (TOF) between the
spallation target and the neutron detector.
In experiment six detectors were used, placed at angles
of 15, 30, 60, 90, 120 and 150 deg. A 10 mm thick
NE102A plastic scintillation detector was placed in
front of each neutron detector and used as
veto detector to suppress detection of charged
particles.
Ionization fission chamber with 238U was used
to determine incident neutron flux.
Experiments were performed at the
Weapons Neutron Research (WNR) facility in Los Alamos
Neutron Science Center (LANSCE)
Neutrons generated by 800 MeV protons
impinging on a tungsten spallation target. The
neutron energies covered a wide energy range up to
750 MeV.The distance between the spallation target
and the experimental room was about 90 m.
Energy of the primary neutron was determined by
time of flight between spallation target and NE213
detector. Flash gamma ray peak was used as time
reference in time of flight.
Natural In sample with diameter of 50 mm and
thickness of 10 mm. Distance between sample and each
detector was about 0.7 m.
Preliminary data unobtainable from authors.
Final data may be available at the end of 2012.
